Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery column-krater; interior glazed streaky black; exterior: neck black; checquer pattern pattern at top of shoulder; below, black-figure decoration consisting of head and shoulder of bearded dancer to left wearing fillet and tunic, with added red on face, neck and tunic.
Producer name: Manner/Style of: The KY Painter (Komast Group)
Curator's comments: This sherd comes from side B of the same vase as British Museum 1888,0601.599.a and 1888,0601.599.c. Another sherd from side B is Oxford AN1896-1908-G.128.18.
Bibliographic references: Beazley & Payne 1929 / Attic Black Figured Fragments from Naukratis (p. 256, no. 12)
Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (p. 195-7, no. 35)
Beazley 1944 / Groups of Early Attic Black Figure (p. 48, no. 2)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 261, no. B182)
Venit 1984 / Early Attic Black Figure Vases in Egypt (p. 147, note 43, no. 14)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 228, no 15)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0123) (Phase 1)
Alexandridou 2011 / The Early Black-Figured Pottery of Attika in Context (c. 630-570BCE) (p. 123) (Naukratis 100)
